source.title: Pañcatantra
source.author: Viṣṇuśarman
source.description: Five books of animal fables designed to teach nīti (wise conduct) to princes. The prose narrative sections are simpler than the embedded verses, making them excellent for early reading practice.

passages.title: The Foolish Princes
passages.sanskrit: अस्ति दक्षिणापथे महिलारोप्यं नाम नगरम् । तत्र अमरशक्तिः नाम राजा बभूव ।
passages.padaccheda: अस्ति दक्षिण-आपथे महिला-रोप्यम् नाम नगरम् तत्र अमरशक्तिः नाम राजा बभूव
passages.transliteration: asti dakṣiṇā-pathe mahilāropyan nāma nagaram | tatra amaraśaktiḥ nāma rājā babhūva |
passages.translation: In the southern region there is a city named Mahilāropya. There, a king named Amaraśakti lived.
passages.grammarNotes:
This is a classic story-opening formula:

1. **अस्ति + locative**: Standard narrative opener "there is/was in [place]"

2. **नाम**: Indeclinable meaning "by name" or "named"

3. **Perfect tense**: बभूव (from √भू) - the reduplicated perfect, used for past narrative

passages.title: The King's Sorrow
passages.sanskrit: तस्य त्रयः पुत्राः परमदुर्मेधसः बभूवुः । तान् दृष्ट्वा राजा चिन्तयामास ।
passages.padaccheda: तस्य त्रयः पुत्राः परम-दुर्मेधसः बभूवुः तान् दृष्ट्वा राजा चिन्तयामास
passages.transliteration: tasya trayaḥ putrāḥ parama-durmedhasaḥ babhūvuḥ | tān dṛṣṭvā rājā cintayām āsa |
passages.translation: He had three sons who were extremely dull-witted. Seeing them, the king reflected.
passages.grammarNotes:
Key constructions:

1. **Genitive of possession**: तस्य पुत्राः "his sons" - genitive shows relationship

2. **Absolutive/gerund**: दृष्ट्वा "having seen" - from √दृश् + त्वा. Indicates action completed before the main verb

3. **Periphrastic perfect**: चिन्तयामास (चिन्तय + आम् + आस) - common for causatives and denominatives

passages.title: The King's Lament
passages.sanskrit: किम् एभिः पुत्रैः यैः न विद्या न विनयः अधिगतः । जातमात्रः खलु गर्दभः अपि मातृपितृभ्याम् बहुमन्यते ।
passages.padaccheda: किम् एभिः पुत्रैः यैः न विद्या न विनयः अधिगतः जात-मात्रः खलु गर्दभः अपि मातृ-पितृभ्याम् बहुमन्यते
passages.transliteration: kim ebhiḥ putraiḥ yaiḥ na vidyā na vinayaḥ adhigataḥ | jāta-mātraḥ khalu gardabhaḥ api mātṛ-pitṛbhyām bahumanyate |
passages.translation: What use are these sons by whom neither learning nor discipline has been acquired? Even a donkey, as soon as born, is valued by its mother and father.
passages.grammarNotes:
Rhetorical techniques:

1. **किम् + instrumental**: "What [use] with...?" - rhetorical question expressing futility

2. **Relative-correlative**: यैः...अधिगतः "by whom...was acquired" - relative clause

3. **Dual instrumental**: मातृपितृभ्याम् "by both mother and father" - the dual number

4. **मात्र suffix**: जातमात्र "just born, as soon as born"

passages.title: The Lion and the Bull - Opening
passages.sanskrit: अस्ति मथुरायां वर्धमानो नाम वणिक् । स एकदा गाडीभ्यां बहुधनं गृहीत्वा व्यापाराय प्रस्थितः ।
passages.padaccheda: अस्ति मथुरायाम् वर्धमानः नाम वणिक् सः एकदा गाडीभ्याम् बहु-धनम् गृहीत्वा व्यापाराय प्रस्थितः
passages.transliteration: asti mathurāyāṃ vardhamāno nāma vaṇik | sa ekadā gāḍībhyāṃ bahu-dhanaṃ gṛhītvā vyāpārāya prasthitaḥ |
passages.translation: In Mathura there is a merchant named Vardhamāna. One day, taking much wealth in two carts, he set out for trade.
passages.grammarNotes:
Narrative progression:

1. **Same opening formula**: अस्ति + locative + नाम

2. **Dative of purpose**: व्यापाराय "for trade" - the dative case expressing purpose

3. **Absolutive sequence**: गृहीत्वा...प्रस्थितः "having taken...set out" - action sequence

4. **Past passive participle**: प्रस्थितः "set out, departed" (from प्र + √स्था)
